text: Draft... Hazy amber ale with dirty-orange highlights and a large, rocky, white head. Good retention. The nose is a mingling of toasted grains, citrus peel, pink peppercorns and a light note of spicy farmhouse yeast. Medium to full-bodied with jazzy carbonation. The flavor presents pink peppercorns, toasted grains, a modest measure of citrus zest and a light pinch of clove. Snappy, peppery, dry finish.

On tap at the brewpub. Clear gold pour with a creamy white head. Huge aromatics on this beer, with pepper, flowers of all kinds, citrus peel. Flavor follows the smell with some nice citrus rind, a little spiciness, low to medium sweetness. This comes out very refreshing, there is a little lingering straw flavor, and it finishes crisp as can be. Light body with medium to high carbonation. This was actually very nice and you could drink it all day long in the sun.
In draft at brewpub, poured a golden yellow color with aromas of hay, light pepper, and some yeast. Flavors follow suit, a nice blonde ale with some flavor, decent beer overall.
Pours gold with a white head. Smell floral, hops and pepper. Taste peppercorn, yeast, floral, and some fruit. Really nice beer!
Pretty light and drinkable with notes of light grain, slightly spicy yeast notes, and a touch of pepper in the finish.

Growler pour thanks to Sean! Pours clear golden orange with a medium creamy off-white head that slowly dissipates leaving nice lacing. Aroma is hay, honey, yeast, pepper. Flavor is about the same, medium sweet, just a touch of bitter and some pepper bite, but that is more prominent in the aftertaste. Medium body. Drinkable for sure, but nothing to write home about.

On draft at the brewpub. Pours a hazy orange-gold with a white head. Nose is some sweet malt, some pepper, some yeast, and floral notes. Flavor is similar- yeast, pepper, floral, and some sweet malt. I love the added complexity from the peppercorns. Medium in body and nice overall.
Aroma is mild citrus, appearance is golden, taste is little bitter little fruit, overall ok

7/10/13. On tap at the brewpub. Clear golden pour with a thick off-white head. The aroma shows peppercorn, pale malts, and light breadiness. Peppercorn and various spices in the flavor with a bitter kick and more of that bready maltiness. Interesting and tasty.
growler thanks homer321. pours orange with fluffy white head. spicy citrus aroma. taste is peppery lemon zest with a very crisp finish.

Draft at CCB Brewpub - Pours a hazy orange w/ a solid white foam head. Smells very citrusy. Tastes of oranges and tangerines with pepper and bitter finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours gold with a thin white head. Aroma of floral hops and pepper. Taste is bitter very peppery between the yeast and the peppercorns with a touch of fruitiness. Very interesting

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Cigar City Brewpub. Pours a dark orange with a off white head and nice, pleasant aroma of peppercorn and flowers. Taste is spicy, with peppercorn, floral, hoppy, and citrus notes coming through leading to dry, bitter finish. Very nice, tasty brew

Dark rusty orange rusty pour with a nice head. On tap at the Brewpub, Tampa. Nose is floral, like fresh flowers with a perfume of light citrus. Taste is yeasty and peppery with great flavor. Nice lacing and finishes on spicey notes. Quaff Score 7 / 10

On tap at Cigar City Brewpub in Carrollwood, FL. Another brew that I was really impressed with. The peppercorns came through incredibly well and added balance that I imagine may have been lacking in the original La Rubia. That being said, I never had that one, so I can't really judge.

Aroma of floral and spice, dark appearance with a small head, smooth taste with a warm finish and a complex, changing mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Growler shared thanks to scotchzi! Pours a hazy yellow with fluffy white head that leaves moderate lacing. Aroma of Belgian yeast, slight spicy and citrus esters. Taste follows, a nice spicy sweet back end, can taste the peppercorn more than smelling it. Solid, interesting.
